text: greetings my name is Matt Word and I'm
here at the AWS headquarters in Seattle
to give you an update on cloud watch
events cloud watch events enables you to
respond to changes in your AWS
environment such as a new ec2 instance
starting or stopping in real time and
you can create rules to respond to
changes in application availability or
configuration from the AWS management
console we have two new features to add
today the first is that cloud watch
events now supports Amazon SQS queue
targets in addition to routing events of
interest to lambda functions for service
execution or to SNS topics for fan-out
or mobile push you can now send them to
an Amazon s qsq you might want to do
this if you had a fleet of workers
pulling off the queue to respond to
those events which is a very common
pattern for our customers the second
feature is the support for lambda
functions versions and aliases this
means you can now refer to a specific a
degree lambda function version in your
cloud watch events rules you can also
create an alias for your function
inversion for example test or production
and refer to this alias in your cloud
watch events rules this means you can
push an update to a lambda function and
have all of your rules update just by
pointing the alias to the new function
two new features for cloud watch events
available today
